awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Residents' Interactions with the State
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project seeks to better understand the link between power-sharing and target-communities' sense of attachment to the state. Conventional wisdom in political science indicates that power-sharing institutions can foster loyalty to the state among certain target groups, such as ethnic minority citizens. However, existing studies have found inconclusive evidence. Additionally, existing research has yet to identify mechanisms linking power-sharing and attachment to the state. This research seeks to address these gaps. Based on an original dataset of household survey and qualitative interviews with local residents and civil servants, it examines power-sharing at the local level of government. Its contribution to the literature lies in a careful tracing and elucidation of the interactions between the target citizens and the state via its agents (the civil servants) and how these interactions shape citizens' view of and attachment to government. This work will inform policymakers that the way in which public service is delivered in a micro-level interaction between citizens and local agents of the state has consequential implications for the way some residents view government institutions.
 
This research project seeks to answer to the following questions: (1) what shapes ethnic minority citizens' sense of attachment to the state?, and (2) why has the state been more successful in winning over a sense of attachment from members of some ethnic minority groups than other groups? To answer these questions, it takes a multi-method approach and uses an original dataset, consisting of household survey data and ethnic minority groups' actual level of representation at various levels of government. It proposes to test a set of hypotheses through regression analysis, and builds on existing literature on power-sharing, but takes a novel approach that focuses on power-sharing at the local -- rather than national -- level of government. Empirically, it goes well beyond showing correlation between the dependent and independent variables of interest; it estimates the effect of power-sharing with ethnic minorities at the national, regional, and local levels of government on their attachment to the state and addresses why and how the effects occur.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Findings: 

This project has documented the extent of the state?s reach in three distinct contexts in Myanmar. First, weak states have the capacity to regulate its citizens by enforcing them to register their person and household. Ordinary citizens by and large comply with the state?s demand for registration. Second, the findings indicate that even in the precarious context of post-coup Myanmar, which is often described as near state collapse, the majority of ordinary citizens continued to visit street-level bureaucracy. Moreover, the findings also indicate that residents of the borderlands in Myanmar? individuals who are beyond the infrastructural reach of the state? also visited street-level bureaucracy to a large extent. These findings speak to the sheer prevalence of mundane encounters with the state.  

An important finding from this project is that the mundane encounters with the state have important implications for ethnic minorities? attachment to the state and their acceptance of the state?s political authority. The data collected indicate that ethnic minorities who have had positive mundane encounters with the state exhibit stronger attachment to the state. This finding is evident in the pre-coup data as well as in the post-coup data from Myanmar.

Intellectual merit: 

Findings from this project contributes to a deeper understanding of how weak states function and determinants of minority-state relations. As political scientists, we know a lot about what weak states cannot do, and have largely overlooked what weak states can do despite their limitations. This project underscores how weak states utilize quotidian acts of services (e.g., providing official documents of registration and ownership) to generate attachment and acceptance of its political authority particularly among ethnic minorities citizens. By focusing on quotidian acts of services, this project advances a new perspective that mundane encounters with the state, though not always positive, can be positive; and when they are positive, they can facilitate stronger attachment to the state. This perspective shifts the focus on structural factors? which have been the prevailing explanations for ethnic minorities? attachment to the state? to individuals? interpersonal experiences with the state. 

Broader impact: 

This project impacts a scholarly community in the global south, faculty diversity, and policymaking. 

First, this project involved training 25 Burmese research assistants, most of whom were ethnic minorities in Myanmar society. The workshops consisted of training in research methodology as well as human subject training. Additionally, the survey protocol of the project was disseminated to students at a community school in Myanmar; and many students used it as a template for designing their own research projects. Furthermore, the co-PI presented research methodology and findings of the project to 4 community schools in Myanmar. These activities contribute to expansion of social science education and research methodology to an underreached context. 

Second, receiving this grant and completion of this project have significantly contributed toward professional development of the co-PI who is now an incoming (tenure track) assistant professor at a flagship public university. Given the co-PI?s background as a first-generation college student from an underrepresented group, her new role contributes toward faculty diversity in American universities. The co-PI will harness her new role to introduce and deepen interests in social science research among students from underserved and underreached communities.  

Finally, on the policy front, this study advances service delivery reform as a strategy in national reconciliation processes in societies affected by armed conflict.
